instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message:
This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board kernel panics intermittently, especially when the CPU is stressed. 

I came to me with an LCD backlight and a fan-related issue, both were fixed. Now, when I run CPU-testing apps like Novabench or TechTool Pro, the machine panics and restarts. Iâ€™ve tried SMC and VRAM reset, as well as DFU Revive.
[ATTACH]60945[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60946[/ATTACH]
Is there any chance this is not a failing CPU and instead something else on the logic board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message: Save data and try DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message: The DFU Restore proceeded fine, but now I can't install an OS because the machine kernel panics at some time during the installation, every time I try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message:
What was the problem causing backlight and fan issue?
Try the installation using external monitor; disconnect internal LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message:
On external display, I managed to install the OS but kernel panics resumed right afterwards with the same CPU:UNKNOWN error.

The machine originally came with no LCD backlight and the right fan blowing continuously. I found <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> was always 12V instead of 8V, which I fixed by replacing the backlight components <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>. The fan circuitry had a missing PMW resistor <RESISTOR>R6052</RESISTOR>  (knocked off), which I replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message:
Check for other knocked off components.
If can't find anything, may have a bad CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message: No such luck. But I noticed that if I unplug the battery, the machine does not kernel panic. Is that because the CPU gets throttled and the faulty core is less likely to be in use?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook Pro with kernel panic
threads.message:
Working without battery, or only battery (no charger), CPU will not work to full specs.
Just in case, test with another battery.
